verses.text: David left there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all his father’s household heard, they went down to him there.
verses.comment: David's withdrawal to the cave shows both his prudence and the beginnings of his band of loyal followers. This is the same cave referenced in the Psalms, hinting at David's great trust in God during affliction.

verses.text: And everyone who was in distress, everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was discontented gathered to him. So he became captain over them. About four hundred men were with him.
verses.comment: The gathering of the marginalized marks David as a type of Christ, attracting those weary and burdened (see Matt. 11:28). His leadership of the disenfranchised prefigures Christ’s gathering of sinners.

verses.text: David went from there to Mizpeh of Moab. He said to the king of Moab, 'Please let my father and mother come and stay with you, until I know what God will do for me.'
verses.comment: David seeks protection for his parents in Moab, which is significant since his great-grandmother Ruth was a Moabite (cf. Ruth 4:17). This act shows a concern for family and a reliance on God’s unfolding plan.

verses.text: He brought them before the king of Moab, and they lived with him all the time that David was in the stronghold.
verses.comment: The Moabite king’s hospitality towards David’s family further points to God’s providence. David’s sojourn echoes the recurring biblical theme where God places His chosen in foreign lands for protection.

verses.text: Then the prophet Gad said to David, 'Do not stay in the stronghold; depart, and go into the land of Judah.' So David departed and came into the forest of Hereth.
verses.comment: Prophet Gad’s guidance confirms God’s direct involvement, ensuring David’s actions align with divine will. Prophecy, as in later times, plays a role in guiding God’s people.

verses.text: Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. Saul was sitting in Gibeah under the tamarisk tree on the height with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.
verses.comment: Saul, seated with spear, is a recurring symbol of his rule and readiness for violence, already estranged from God’s favor. The contrast between David's humble band and Saul’s armed court is striking.

verses.text: Then Saul said to his servants who stood around him, 'Listen now, you Benjaminites! Will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards? Will he make you commanders of thousands and hundreds?'
verses.comment: Saul appeals to tribal loyalty, offering favors and power. This foreshadows the dangers of leadership corrupted by self-interest, contrasting with the fullness of God’s kingdom where true reward is spiritual.

verses.text: 'That all of you have conspired against me! No one reveals to me when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse. None of you is sorry for me or tells me that my son has stirred up my servant against me to lie in wait, as he does this day.'
verses.comment: Saul, growing paranoid, accuses his servants of conspiracy. His reference to the covenant between Jonathan and David underscores the importance of faithfulness, which finds fuller expression in the New Covenant in Christ.

verses.text: Then Doeg the Edomite, who was set over the servants of Saul, spoke and said, 'I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub.'
verses.comment: Doeg's position as an Edomite (a foreigner) in Saul’s court highlights the irony of an outsider betraying the true king, a theme seen elsewhere in Scripture (e.g., Judas in Luke 22:3-6).

verses.text: 'He inquired of the Lord for him, gave him provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.'
verses.comment: Service done for David becomes the point of accusation. The giving of Goliath’s sword recalls past victories granted by God, connecting present trials with God’s ongoing providence.

verses.text: Then the king sent to summon Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and all his father’s household, the priests who were in Nob; and they all came to the king.
verses.comment: All the priests of Nob, the key Levitical city, are summoned. The priests here symbolize the mediation between God and man, foreshadowing later priesthood fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Saul said, 'Listen now, son of Ahitub.' He answered, 'Here I am, my lord.'
verses.comment: Ahimelech’s respectful response, ‘Here I am,’ echoes the biblical tradition of ready service, as seen with Abraham (Gen. 22:1) and Samuel (1 Sam. 3:4).

verses.text: Saul said to him, 'Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, in that you have given him bread and a sword and have inquired of God for him, so that he has risen up against me to lie in wait, as is the case today?'
verses.comment: Saul’s accusation of conspiracy reveals his further alienation from God’s purposes. Food and intercession are portrayed as aiding David, resonating with the Church’s role in sustaining the righteous.

verses.text: Ahimelech answered the king: 'Who among all your servants is as faithful as David, who is the king’s son-in-law, captain of your bodyguard, and honored in your house?'
verses.comment: Ahimelech’s defense asserts David’s faithfulness and position. Faithfulness even amid accusation mirrors Christ before Pilate (John 19:4).

verses.text: Is today the first time I have inquired of God for him? Far from it! Let not the king lay anything to his servant’s charge, or to any of my father’s house. Your servant knew nothing of all this, much or little.'
verses.comment: Ahimelech asserts his innocence, maintaining his loyalty to the king and the Lord—a reminder that obedience to God sometimes leads to being misunderstood or persecuted.

verses.text: But the king said, 'You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father’s house.'
verses.comment: Saul’s irrational decree to kill the priests echoes God’s earlier warning of judgment upon Eli’s house (1 Sam. 2:31-33), showing that prophecy is being fulfilled, despite the king’s own intentions.

verses.text: The king said to the guards who stood around him, 'Turn and kill the priests of the Lord, because their hand also is with David, and because they knew when he fled and did not disclose it to me.' But the servants of the king would not put out their hands to strike the priests of the Lord.
verses.comment: The guards’ refusal shows reverence for the Lord’s anointed, even when commanded otherwise. This respect for sacred offices foreshadows the way God’s people treat the ministers He appoints.

verses.text: Then the king said to Doeg, 'You turn and strike the priests.' So Doeg the Edomite turned and struck down the priests. He killed on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.
verses.comment: Doeg’s violent act fulfills the prophecy against Eli’s house (see 1 Sam. 2:31). The linen ephod marks them as legitimate priests. Desecration of the priesthood is a grave sin throughout salvation history.

verses.text: He put Nob, the city of the priests, to the sword—man and woman, child and infant, ox, donkey, and sheep—he killed with the edge of the sword.
verses.comment: The total destruction recalls earlier commands given to Saul against Amalek (1 Sam. 15:3) that Saul failed to carry out. Ironically, Saul does here what he previously would not, but now against God’s servants.

verses.text: But one of the sons of Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled after David.
verses.comment: Abiathar’s escape preserves the priestly line, showing God’s faithfulness to His promises (see 1 Sam. 2:35). Abiathar becomes high priest under David, an anointed mediator between God and king.

verses.text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
verses.comment: David is made aware of Saul’s extreme measures. The sharing of this news strengthens the tragic divide between Saul and God’s appointed order, underscoring the importance of right leadership and priestly mediation.

verses.text: David said to Abiathar, 'I knew on that day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would surely tell Saul. I am responsible for the lives of all your father’s house.'
verses.comment: David’s admission of responsibility and sorrow foreshadows Christ’s bearing of the consequences for others (see John 10:11). He acts as a true shepherd, accepting responsibility for his flock.

verses.text: 'Stay with me; do not be afraid. For he who seeks your life seeks my life also. With me you will be under protection.'
verses.comment: David promising safety and solidarity to Abiathar is reminiscent of Christ’s assurance to His followers (John 10:28), providing spiritual and physical protection even amidst persecution. True leaders offer refuge and guidance to the persecuted.
